SW, This should not be an either / or situation. There are many programs in place in the U.S. to help our needy children -- programs that both President and Mrs. Obama have championed and which many in Congress would like to discontinue.

This, however, is a an urgent humanitarian issue that should be treated as such. Children are children no matter where they come from, and should not be used as political footballs. When a baby is left on your doorstep you don't kick it to the curb. You take it in and care for it while you figure out what to do.

I suppose I should consider myself fortunate that I am not a writer by profession. I am very new to fiction writing, which I started only two years ago. I have been taking writing workshops, and also have been a part of a group of writers who read and critique each others works. The only fiction I have ever written professionally has been legal briefs.

I say I am fortunate, because I don't think I have any ideas that anyone would want to steal, and I don't have any pieces of writing that anyone would want to plagiarize. So I feel comfortable with and very trusting of the company I keep. I truly believe that my writing has improved substantially because of the feedback I have been receiving from my instructor, my fellow classmates, and my writing circle colleagues.

For this novice, having access to a community of writers has been beneficial from an artistic and craft standpoint, as well as socially. I truly like my new friends, whom I never would have met had it not been for my signing up for that first fiction writing workshop class.

Maybe someday, if I ever write that Great American Novel, I too will have the same concerns that have been expressed by other commenters. I hope not though - I would very much miss the camaraderie and community of my new friends.

@GerryCollinsPVNY:

Perhaps it's time to define "crony capitalism." Many democratic voters routinely decry it, but they also rely on the elites like Krugman to tell them when it's an okay time to do so.

The posting ignores that most all of these services are available from private sector financiers, especially when shipments are made to the countries of the G-20, with highly developed financial infrastructures.

Mr. Heim can hardly claim with any level of credibility that his overseas customers cannot secure financing in countries like the UK, Germany, France, Australia, or Japan. It is simply that such financing isn't as cheap as it is with the ExIm; thus, the ExIm lives up to its reputation as "corporate welfare."

Certainly, the federal government can assist with export financing to developing nations or regions in Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and Asia where the financial infrastructure is less developed. But that, too, can be managed by the private sector in the same fashion that Germany manages its Hermes covers.

The ExIm has been shown to be shot through with corporate paid perks and so inclined to be a captive finance company of large, politically connected companies like GE, Boeing, and Caterpillar that even considering extending it's charter amounts to congressional approval of the type of "crony capitalism" and governmental corruption that Americans have made more than clear they will no longer tolerate.

Congress, extend the ExIm --- at your peril.

Well said. If the conversation was about guns, there would be all kinds of nuance and information and bragging about how much they know, but since it's about women's health choices, it's all about "recreational" or "promiscuous sex".

A facelift also involves consultation with a doctor, but that does not make it health care.  Contaception and contra-implantation devices and drugs are not health care unless the hormones are being used to treat a hormonal disorder.  Don't conflate prevention of pregnancy with prevention of illness.

I'm struck by the the Court's and many commenters lack of understanding of women's health and the effect that contraception plays in it.  Contraception used by women (excepting condoms worn by men) requires consultation with doctor, and is therefore properly a part of holistic medical care.  It should be covered in any health insurance policy.  That the members of the Court don't seem to know (or care) about this, and than many commenters here don't get it either is testament to the still pervasive misogyny in our society.

Interesting and well written (as always!) piece. I must respectfully disagree with these business owners to a degree, however, as a lawyer and as a brand new small business owner myself.  I think that the necessity of a lawyer, or the degree to which you need to involve a lawyer in your business, really depends on the size, scope and complexity of your business.  I also think that if you're in an industry where laws (or their application) are changing or developing rapidly, you would be reckless in NOT consulting a lawyer.  On the other hand, I also think that, in the same way that you have to advocate for your own healthcare, it's very important to know how to manage your lawyers.  Question them and be your own advocate.  But don't assume that because you've seen one contract or term sheet or trust indenture (or whatever it may be) that you've seen them all and don't need professional guidance.  Just manage that professional guidance.

They're free to control them. Your employer is not obligated to buy your control.

Your job is your benefit, especially now.

Thank you - I sent this essay to my wife, whose father paid a surrogate mother a large sum of money to bear his children when his wife could not.

Now as an adult born into privelege, my wife struggles with the existential angst of a purchased existence.

I was conceived in a one night stand on New Years Eve by two wonderful people who wld have no relationship with each other but for my life, so I have long ago reconciled my existence as a matter of chance or unknown destiny.

While I'd like to think there was a larger purpose, sometimes it all seems like just what happened before we got here. And maybe it's not that big of a deal.
